channel.title: Historical Income Panel for the Netherlands
channel.description: Recent content on Historical Income Panel for the Netherlands

item.title: Population register archeology
item.description: Population registers are crucial for identifying the taxed individuals in our project. We rely heavily on volunteer ❤️ transcriptions, such as those hosted by archieven.nl. However, these registers don’t always provide the necessary information for efficient identification. For example, knowing the time period a register covers is vital, but source notes can lack this information. Similarly, archives sometimes combine registers from multiple municipalities, making it difficult to distinguish between them.

A slidedeck presenting the state of the project and inequality trends in the Netherlands can be found here

item.title: The HIP-NL data
item.description:
The data produced can be found at the UU’s Yoda repository.

A Linked Data version is hosted at the IISH’s triplestore.

item.title: The sample
item.description: The HIP-NL data is a sample of 79 municipalities over the c. 1860–1920 period. We sample municipalities because we need to be able to infer incomes for the missing population, which is only possible if we have the entire taxed population for a given municipality. The sampled municipalities and the number of tax observations they provided are listed below.

item.title: HIP-NL at the 2023 Posthumus conference
item.description: Eva will present about the HIP-NL project at the Posthumus Conference. We’re in the session on Fiscal sources for the study of inequality on Wednesday the 24th, 1500.

item.title: Team
item.description:
• Auke Rijpma
  • Paul Puschmann
  • Eva van der Heijden
  • Rick Schouten

item.title: The HIP-NL project
item.description: The Historical Income Panel for the Netherlands project (HIP-NL) is creating a unique large-scale historical income panel. Using municipal tax records income estimates at 10-year intervals will be gathered for c. 200,000 individuals in the Netherlands between 1851 and 1922. Recent mass digitisation of vital records and population registers, as well as the development of data integration tools means we will be able to connect the income panel to many other important economic and social history datasets, and answer questions about social and economic inequality over a long time frame, across multiple dimensions, and over multiple generations.
